snippet: Higher income parents spend more on nearly every item with a discretionary component. That adds up to Montessori instead of in-home day care, houses in stronger school districts, and more money spent on activities, travel, and other miscellany that...
abstract: Higher income parents spend more on nearly every item with a discretionary component. That adds up to Montessori instead of in-home day care, houses in stronger school districts, and more money spent on activities, travel, and other miscellany that the lower-income child either doesn’t “need” or just doesn’t get.

headline.main: What We Spend to Raise a Child — and What We Don't
